newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: PRESS DIGEST-Australian Business News - June 17.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST-Australian Business News - June 17.

text.p: THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL REVIEW

BHP has stated it will not publicise its plans concerning the sale of its remaining 5.1 per cent stake in the Foster's Brewing Group. This has caused anxiety among small BHP shareholders who remain uncertain as to how the massive sell-off will affect their assets in the long term. Page 19.

Singapore Airlines is seeking to buy one third of Ansett Holdings Ltd in a deal estimated to be worth between A$200 and A$300 million. As part of the deal still being negotiated News Corp Ltd and Air New Zealand Ltd would reduce their current half holdings to one third each, allowing Singapore Airlines to become a equal partner. Page 19.

The A$220 million Bass Strait Royalty Trust float is expected to close this Friday on schedule, with reserved institutional interest in the issue being shown. Lead managers of the enterprise County NatWest said they were happy with the investor response, ith retail interest having been particularly strong. Page 20.

Giant Australian insurance group, the AMP Society looks set to abandon plans for a take-over of British insurance and financial services group Norwich Union. The recent valuation of Norwich Union at A$14.4 billion is an investment AMP is not capable of making, especially in the lead up to its own demutalisation. Page 20.

Queensland dairy products company QUF Industries Ltd announced yesterday it was expecting a strong full-year profit result for 1996-1997. On account of this it was postponing a planned dividend reinvestment plan because, in light of improved cash flows and improved earnings, the need for new capital had been reduced. Page 24

Troubled grocery company Davids Ltd has appointed Jeff David sole managing director of the firm, and appointed former Consolidated Press finance director and Brierley Investments director Don Bourke as temporary chief financial officer. The management changes came yesterday as the company announced the merger of its Jewel and Davids distribution divisions. Page 25.
THE AUSTRALIAN

Gas giant Boral yesterday revealed plans to become a dominant player in Australia's gas market when it becomes deregulated. A major part of this is Boral's launch of a A$400 million specialist listed distribution vehicle called Envestra, which aims to prvide gas distribution networks in South Australia, Queensland and the Northern Territory. Page 21

Consolidated Gold Fields has started operations at a 120,000 ounce a year Davyhurst gold project 120 kilometres north west of Kalgoorlie in Western Australia. The mine became operational last Friday and is expected to reach maximum production levels over the next month. Page 22

Former co-operative Australian Pharmaceutical Industries yesterday listed on the Australian Stock Exchange. Managing director Ron Rowland said the company was planning to expand into the untapped hospital supply market, worth approximately A$1.5 billion annually, and was capable of achieving A$1 billion sales this financial year. Page 22

A environmental report to be released today casts doubt on the viability of Ross Mining NL's Gold Ridge project in the Solomon Islands. The report's authors, Monash University, claim that tailings from the mine would pollute the island's river systems, thus giving further support to landowners downstream from the proposed project who are seeking increased compensation from Ross Mining NL. Page 23.

Industry observers expect new Optus Communications chief executive Peter Howell-Davies to delay Optus' planned share market float until next year. The float would be postponed pending the restructuring of the company's pay TV business, which is a persistent profit drain. Page 23.

The Australian mining industry has blamed the Federal Government's lack of clear leadership over native title issues for delays in exploring the Gawler Craton region in South Australia, considered to be potentially Australia's richest resource area. Companies wishing to investigate the area are facing native title and heritage obstacles. Page 23.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

The 22-month long investigation by the Australian Securities Commission into the Coles Myer and Yannon transactions is nearing completion, with ASC chairman Alan Cameron commenting that the matter was proceeding satisfactorily. Coles Myer has blamed its involvement in the affair, which cost it A$18 million, on former executive chairman Brian Quinn and former finance director John Banner. Page 25.

New Zealand entrepreneur Graeme Hart yesterday revealed himself as the mystery buyer of A$215 million worth of Burns, Philp & Co shares. The acquisition of a 14.9 per cent holding places him in an advantageous position for a future take-over of the troubed food ingredients group. Page 25.

Federal Foreign Affairs and Trade Minister Alexander Downer yesterday said Australia has reached an agreement with Indonesia to explore possible partnerships between the car industries of both countries. The move comes in the wake of an international trade dispute between the US, Japan, and the European Union, and Indonesia over the latter's national car program, which receives exclusive tax and tariff concessions. Page 26.

A joint housing survey by Citibank and Real Estate Institute of Australia has revealed that despite rising property prices, a combination of higher income levels and plummeting interest rates have made the average Sydney home more affordable. However, the REIA warned that changes to the last budget towards higher capital gains tax would minimise these benefits for property investors. Page 27.

Australian resource stocks have experienced a lacklusture performance despite the sharemarket's latest record rise, and would have to depend on a surge in metal prices to kick-off another rally. Demand for resource stocks have declined as institutional investors feel current prices already reflect their full value. Page 28.

The Seven Network's 50 per cent owned film studio, Metro-Goldwyn Mayer, is expected to float on the US sharemarket at the end of this year according to US entertainment journal Variety. The move comes 12 months ahead of schedule with MGM hoping to raise aout A$400 million. Page 27.
THE AGE

Industry observers predict Cable & Wireless will complete its domination of Optus Communications early this week when it buys out fellow shareholder BellSouth Corp. The proposed acquisition would give Cable & Wireless a 49 per cent stake, and undisputed control, in the company. Page B1.

The newly appointed chairman of General Motors Holden, Jim Wiemels, has advised the Australian car industry it needs to assist South-East Asian countries to develop internationally competitive car industries if it values free access to their markets. Speaking at the Federation of Automotive Products Manufacturers conference on the weekend, Wiemels said South -East Asian countries would only allow participation in their markets on a partnership basis. Page B3.

BHP has shutdown the operations of its second semi-autogenous mill at its Ok Tedi site in Papua New Guinea following a dry season and low water levels in the Fly River. The river serves as the sole supply channel in and out of the mine. Page B2.

The Vic Government's port reforms have ended with its awarding of a 10-year contact to TNT to manage the Port of Hastings. TNT will pay the State a royalty in accordance to trade levels, expected to be around A$650,000. Page B3

The constant rumours of an imminent takeover bid for one of the big four Australian banks is misplaced, as at current share prices these institutions are simply too expensive. The National Australia Bank is trading at 2.5 times net tangible assets, while the other three banks are priced 2.2 times NTA. Page B3

Carlton United Breweries is free to sell its 2.2 percent stake in Crown Ltd following its decision to break its 1993 pre-emptive rights agreement with Hudson Conway. While CUB's 16.07 million shares is worth about A$33.3 million, a spokesman for the company said it was not looking to sell the shares at this stage. Page B3
